Key Concepts

üîπ HTTP Is Stateless

  • Every request is independent

  • State is simulated via:

    • Cookies
    • Session tokens
    • Hidden form fields
    • URL parameters

Security implication:

State management is attack surface.

üîπ Trust Boundaries

Trust boundaries exist between:

  • Browser ‚Üî Web Server
  • Web Server ‚Üî App Server
  • App Server ‚Üî Database
  • Internal services ‚Üî External APIs

Security failures often occur at:

  • Data validation boundaries
  • Authentication checks
  • Authorization transitions

üîπ Client-Side vs Server-Side Trust

Never trust:

  • JavaScript validation
  • Hidden form fields
  • Disabled buttons
  • Client-side access control

Core principle:

All client-controlled data is attacker-controlled.

  • TDD development

We are doing test driven development. For each task, do the following:

  1. Add a test to the test file specified by the user.
  2. Run the tests and ensure it fails. If it doesn‚Äôt stop.
  3. Add the implementation to the implementation file specified by the user.
  4. Run the tests and ensure it passes. If it doesn‚Äôt attempt to fix it by changing only the implementation.
  5. Commit it, starting the commit message with ü§ñ do denote the commit was done by you.
  6. Stop and wait for the next task.

If the task involves refactoring, take small steps figure out a sequence of small moves that minimize the amount of time the code is broken. Treat each small step as a task, run the tests, and commit after each one.

If the user doesn‚Äôt specify test and implementation files, stop and ask the user before continuing. DO NOT USE TOOLS TO TRY TO FIND THE FILES.
